channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Wave of Car Bombs Kills Dozens in Iraq
item.description: A deadly upsurge of violence in Iraq claimed more victims Monday when 15 car bombs killed at least 46 people and injured many more, according to security sources.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: A charred car rests in Sadr City, a district in Baghdad. Ten car bombs exploded in Baghdad early Monday, mainly in Shiite neighborhoods.

item.title: Son of Fallen Chinese Official Enrolls at Columbia Law School
item.description: It is unclear how Bo Guagua, the son of Bo Xilai, will pay for his three-year education at Columbia, which has one of the most expensive law schools in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and AMY QIN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 29
item.description: A man blowing a conch shell in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man blowing a conch shell on the first Monday of the Hindu month of Sawan, in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: German Magazine Accused Over Historical Views
item.description: A Jewish group’s complaint against the magazine Der Landser has added to the debate over the balance between free speech and efforts in Germany to eradicate the neo-Nazi movement.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Pope Says He Will Not Judge Gay Priests
item.description: “If someone is gay and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?” Francis was quoted as saying on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Pope Francis during a press conference on the flight to Italy from Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Listening Post: U.S. Pushes for Global Eye on South Sudan Conflict
item.description: Officials said they want to draw attention to what could become a humanitarian tragedy, but they are also working to preserve an Obama administration achievement.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: India Ink: After the Delhi Rape, Small Victories for Women in India’s Popular Culture
item.description: Seven months after the Delhi rape, India’s popular culture continues to fail the gender test.
item.dc:creator: By SNIGDHA POONAM
item.media:description: Protesters being hit by a police water cannon during a demonstration against the gang rape of a 23-year-old student in New Delhi on Dec. 23, 2012.

item.title: Labor Rights Group Accuses iPhone Maker of Abuses
item.description: China Labor Watch said it had found violations of the law and of Apple’s pledges about working conditions at factories operated by a Taiwanese company, Pegatron.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Cash Lure Cast From the Temple
item.description: The archbishop of Canterbury is waging war on Wonga, one of the biggest high-interest lenders, with the aim to drive the company out of business.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: A Reunion for War Survivors Who Escaped to India
item.description: How thousands of Poles survived the Nazis and the Russians during the World War II and found refuge in India.
item.dc:creator: By NARESH FERNANDES
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Tadeusz Dobrostanski in "The Second Homeland" book by Anuradha Bhattacharjee published by SAGE publications.
item.media:description: Jam Saheb, center, with Polish children, in Jamnagar, Gujarat, in 1944.

item.title: 38 People Killed as Bus Plunges Off Highway in Italy
item.description: The highway police told state radio that the bus slammed into slowing cars and plunged down a ravine about 160 miles south of Rome.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Cambodian Opposition Rejects Election Results
item.description: Leaders of the country’s newly energized opposition on Monday accused Prime Minister Hun Sen’s authoritarian government of large-scale cheating.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Sam Rainsy, the president of the Cambodia National Rescue Party, said on Monday at a news conference that his party "cannot accept the result" of the election.

item.title: Garry Davis, Man of No Nation Who Saw One World of No War, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. Davis was a self-declared world citizen who tirelessly advocated to erase national borders and to end wars as part of the One World movement.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Garry Davis, dean of the One World movement, in 1956. He had his own flag and passport, and often his own jail cell.

item.title: Crackdown in Egypt Kills Islamists as They Protest
item.description: The Egyptian authorities unleashed a ferocious attack on Islamist protesters, killing at least 72 people in the second mass killing of demonstrators in three weeks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: In Old City of Damascus, War Closes In
item.description: Straight Street has been known since at least the early years of Christianity for its ramrod course through the twisting alleys of the old city of Damascus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Protesters Press Tunisian Government to Resign, as Ruling Party Supporters Rally
item.description: Protests for the the government and the National Constituent Assembly to resign continued around the country Sunday on the fourth day after the assassination of an opposition legislator.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Thief Gets Away With Estimated $50 Million in Jewelry at a French Riviera Hotel
item.description: The crime at the Carlton Intercontinental came days after a member of a gang of jewel thieves escaped from a Switzerland prison.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
item.media:description: French police kept watch outside the Carlton Intercontinental Hotel along the Promenade de la Croisette in Cannes.

item.title: News Analysis: Weak Finish From Europe on Chinese Solar Panels
item.description: The European Commission’s antidumping case against China started vigorously but foundered amid European political divisions; it may ultimately strengthen China’s solar industry.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Ukrainian Court Fines Feminist Protesters
item.description: A court in Kiev fined three activists of Femen, the Ukrainian feminist organization known for its bare-breasted protests, and a Russian photojournalist on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: Israel and Palestinians Set to Resume Peace Talks, U.S. Announces
item.description: The meeting between negotiators, planned to start Monday and announced by the State Department, will be the first time that the two have held direct talks since 2010.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Syrian Opposition Leader Says He Would Meet Assad Officials
item.description: Ahmad al-Jarba, president of the National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces, says he is prepared to attend a peace conference in Geneva without preconditions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmad al-Jarba of the main Syrian exile opposition group.

item.title: White House Muted in Response to New Mass Killing of Egyptian Protesters
item.description: Democratic and Republican lawmakers, while condemning the second mass killing of demonstrators following the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, stopped short of calling for cutting aid to Egypt.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: This Heroine Wears a Burqa to Fight Evil
item.description: A new cartoon in Pakistan features a role model for female empowerment, but her costume has stirred some controversy.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Damascus Journal: A Link Straight to Syria’s Ancient Past Endures as War Creeps Closer
item.description: Straight Street has been known since at least the early years of Christianity for its ramrod course through the twisting alleys of the old city of Damascus, but now residents fear for its very existence.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Mali Holds Elections After Year of Turmoil
item.description: Under pressure from the West to restore a semblance of democracy, voting proceeds peacefully. An August runoff is likely.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and PETER TINTI
item.media:description: Election workers waited for voters to cast their ballots in Timbuktu, Mali, on Sunday. Voting was reported to be peaceful.
